title: Milestone 4: Scanner
description:
Walk directory tree, find conflict candidates, verify originals, validate hashes.

Files: src/scanner.rs
Dependencies: walkdir

Types used:
- ScanConfig: roots, max_depth, follow_symlinks, include_hidden, case_insensitive
- ConflictCandidate: detected conflicts before verification
- VerificationResult: outcome after hash comparison
- ScanReport: aggregated results

Functions:
- fn scan(config: &ScanConfig) -> io::Result<ScanReport>

Internal steps:
1. Walk directories per ScanConfig
2. Filter by conflict patterns (uses pattern.rs)
3. Check if presumed original exists
4. Hash both files if original exists (uses hash.rs)
5. Classify result: ConfirmedDuplicate / OrphanedConflict / ContentDiverged
6. Aggregate into ScanReport

Testing:
- Integration tests with temp directory structures
- Create known conflict files, verify detection
- Test bundle detection (.pages, .app directories)
- Test .icloud placeholder detection

title: TUI Foundation: Pure layers and effects boundary
description: TUI foundation decomposed along FP/Unix boundaries: pure data (state algebra), pure logic (transitions), pure rendering (widgets), effects (terminal IO), and theme (style constants). Each layer depends only on the layers below it. Intelligence lives in the pure layers; the effects boundary is a thin shell.

title: TUI State Algebra: Pure types for screens, actions, and transitions
description: Define the type algebra that represents the entire TUI state space. Screen variants (each carrying their own state), user Action enum, and transition result types. Pure data — zero effects, zero logic. These types ARE the spec: they make illegal states unrepresentable and define the contract that transitions and rendering implement against.

title: Add ratatui and crossterm deps, create src/tui/ module
description: Add ratatui and crossterm to Cargo.toml. Create src/tui/mod.rs with submodule declarations. Register tui module in lib.rs. Verify it compiles.

title: Define Screen, Action, and Transition types
description: The TUI state algebra: Screen enum (each variant carries per-screen state like cursor/selection), Action enum (semantic user inputs), and Transition enum (describes what should happen — screen change, quit, noop, or side-effect request). Pure data, zero effects. Types reference existing domain types (ScanReport, DuplicateGroup) but don't own them — per-screen state is navigation/selection only. Follows Elm/TEA architecture: transitions return effect descriptions, not perform effects.

title: TUI State Transitions: Pure update function
description: Implement the pure state transition function: given a Screen and an Action, produce the next Screen. This is the core logic of the TUI, fully testable without a terminal. Each screen defines which actions it accepts and what state they produce. Invalid transitions are compile-time or exhaustive-match errors, not runtime surprises.

title: Implement update function: navigation transitions
description: Create src/tui/update.rs with the pure update function. Covers screen-to-screen navigation: Overview number keys, Back from all screens, Enter to drill down, Quit, and list cursor movement (MoveUp/MoveDown with bounds checking). Exhaustive pattern matching.

title: Implement update function: selection and action transitions
description: Extend the update function with in-screen state changes: DuplicateList selection (toggle, all, none), DuplicateDetail actions (skip, quarantine single), Confirm yes/no triggering Effect::StartQuarantine or back. Tests for all screen×action combinations.

title: TUI Pure Rendering: Map state to widget trees
description: Rendering as pure functions: given a Screen state, produce the ratatui widget tree. No side effects, no terminal access — just state in, widgets out. One render function per screen variant. Layout, styling, and text formatting live here. Testable by asserting on the produced widget structure.

title: TUI Effects Boundary: Event loop, terminal, and cleanup
description: The only place where side effects live. Terminal raw mode setup/teardown, crossterm event polling, panic hooks for terminal restoration, resize handling. This is the thin shell that wires pure transitions and pure rendering to the real terminal. Kept minimal — all intelligence lives in the pure layers.

title: TUI Theme: Color semantics and style constants
